Honestly, I came into this film with the wrong mindset. I thought this was going to be another Kevin Costner "Taken" clone, something like "3 Days to Kill". But no, this is far more of a slow burn drama as opposed to a breakneck action film. So, it took me some time to adjust my expectations. With that in mind, the movie has some serious pacing problems. They try to milk scenes for suspense where there is no suspense to be had. A scene does not become tense just because they add in creepy music. There are some good scenes in the movie, but they are too few and far between to make up for all the terrible characters.

Sceneggiatura molto interessante e con pochissime incertezze, con la rodata coppia Costner - Lane al comando, con evidente complicità nel dominare la storia che, grazie ad una sapiente regia, pone i due attori al centro del progetto e fornisce tutti gli elementi per emergere con dialoghi lunghi e profondi, ritmi lenti e sequenze lunghe.
La sceneggiatura si compone di pochi eventi allacciati tra di loro da ottime inquadrature a campo largo alternate appunto ad intensi dialoghi tra i protagonisti.
Il clima di tensione sempre crescente esplode in due sequenze che spiazzano totalmente lo spettatore abituato alla dolcezza blanda del film fino a quel punto e che viene, in modo molto veritiero, schiaffeggiato e riportato alla crudeltà della vita.
Non del tutto chiara è la presenza del giovane "indiano" che probabilmente non viene sfruttato nel modo migliore ma solo "usato" ai fini della trama.

I enjoyed this movie very much. Some people may say it played out too slow but I believe it had to so the audience can absorb and understand the level of danger the Blackledges and their grandchild is/are in. The Weboy’s are a very violent family making them dangerous to all that question their way of living, especially the way they discipline the grandchild. This good vs evil theme keeps you hanging on to the edge of your seat rooting for George and Margaret to protect and save their family. The reason I gave this movie a 4 star rating is because I don’t think George had to die at the hands of the Weboy’s.

A Gripping and Emotional Must-Watch!

Let Him Go, starring Kevin Costner and Diane Lane, is a deeply moving and powerful film that I absolutely recommend. It’s not just a suspenseful thriller—it’s an emotional journey about love, loss, and the unbreakable bond of family.

Costner and Lane deliver breath-taking performances as a couple who embark on a dangerous quest to rescue their grandson from an abusive family. Their quiet strength, resilience, and unwavering love struck me on a deeply personal level. As a survivor of 17 years of systematic and severe child abuse, I found myself completely immersed in their characters. Their pain, determination, and desperate need to protect an innocent child resonated with me in ways I never expected.

The film masterfully balances heart-wrenching emotion with gripping tension. Every scene feels raw and authentic, pulling the viewer into the high-stakes battle between good and evil. The cinematography, the hauntingly beautiful landscapes, and the slow-burn storytelling all contribute to an unforgettable experience.

If you’re looking for a movie that is both thrilling and deeply emotional, Let Him Go is a must-watch. It’s a story about the lengths we go to for those we love, and for anyone who has ever endured or witnessed abuse, it carries an even deeper, more profound impact.

Let him go is a 2020 neo western drama starring Kevin Costner and Diane Lane as a couple mourning the early death of their son, only for their grandson to be taken away by very unsuitable guardians.

Thrilling to watch, heart wrenching to watch and sometimes even shocking to watch. However, Let Him Go is not a revenge film that fit the likeness of John Wick, but rather a soothing and captivating study of how far people will go to save the ones they care about. 

As the poster might mislead you with it being a action film for the elderly, it's certainly not that. But what it holds is a original concept, breakout performances that all credited actors (including a terrifying Lesley Manville) that can't be looked away from and a terrific score make this a very high quality standard of filmmaking indeed.

Overall, while not exactly original, the plot alone is mostly attention grabbing throughout it's runtime, making Let Him Go differ from the things we see today.

Grade: A+
